instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damaged
threads.message: Hi, I have an Air with liquid damage around Type-C ports. <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> (5V 0A ) had a short on one of the 3.3v lines and one got a bit warm, after replacement shorts are gone. Also no short on any of the big coils. Now I get 5.15v 0.02A and then switching to 5.02v and 0.26A and staying there. PPBUS is 12.29V, should be 12.6? What should I check next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damaged
threads.message:
Do you get 1V1 LDO voltage at <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips?
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damaged
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is present
And I get 1.1V on <CAPACITOR>C3104</CAPACITOR>, is that the 1V1 LDO you mean?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damaged
threads.message: Note there was some corrosion on <RESISTOR>R3103</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R3105</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3109</RESISTOR>, i replaced them no shorts and resistance is correct, no change in charging

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damaged
threads.message:
Each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> must get 1V1 LDO, only when the charger is connected to corresponding port.
The other 3 LDOs are always present.

BTW, LDOs are clearly visible inside chip pin notations!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damaged
threads.message:
OK, I measured as follows with charger connected:


               
<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> (charger connected)

<CAPACITOR>C3108</CAPACITOR> = 3.28
<CAPACITOR>C3106</CAPACITOR> = 1.81
<CAPACITOR>C3105</CAPACITOR> = 1.8
<CAPACITOR>C3104</CAPACITOR> = 1.11

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> (charger connected)

<CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR> = 3.3
<CAPACITOR>C3206</CAPACITOR> = 1.8
<CAPACITOR>C3205</CAPACITOR> = 1.8
<CAPACITOR>C3204</CAPACITOR> = 1.1

Seems all LDO lines are OK. I have 3.29 on both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> lines as well as 5v incoming. Would you suggest try other <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s or are there other voltages that need to be present to create 20v?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damaged
threads.message: Check if you get all SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damaged
threads.message: The SLPS2R signals are there and so are the Awake: 1.1, 1.8, 3.3. I noticed the T2 chip getting hotter then the rest of the board by 5 degrees, is this normal or could it be T2 issues?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damaged
threads.message: Test if it is recognized in DFU...
